header.emu_comment: Internet Archive Final Burn Alpha 2012 CPS1 romset listing by Zach Morris. This set is for use with the Retroarch core FBA 2012 CPS1 (v0.2.97.29 / MAME v0.149). This list is the full list of compatible roms available for this set.[CR]Final Burn Alpha is a Multiple Arcade Emulator most popular for emulating Neo-Geo, Capcom, Konami, and Cave games. It is developed by the final burn team and originated from FinalBurn by Dave.

game.name: 1941: Counter Attack (World 900227)
game.plot: 1941 - Counter Attack (c) 1990 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Export release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "1941 - Counter Attack [B-Board 89625B-1]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board ID: 89624B-3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]1941 - Counter Attack was released in February 1990 in arcades outside of Japan.[CR]In the Export releases, at the 5th position on the high score table, it says 'a02' instead of 'j01' in the original Japanese release.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Two version are known to exists:[CR]- USA 900227[CR]- ETC 900227[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released outside Japan. For a list of Japanese ports, please see the original Japanese version entry, "1941 - Counter Attack [B-Board 89625B-1]". [CR]* Consoles : [CR]Microsoft XBOX [US] (November 24, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (November 24, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2 [Model SLUS-21473]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [AU] (April 11, 2007) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2 [Model SLES-54561]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (April 13, 2007) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2 [Model SLES-54561]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Sony PSP [US] (March 22, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Remixed [Model ULUS-10097]" [CR]Sony PSP [EU] (July 21, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Remixed [Model ULES-00347]" [CR]* Others : [CR]Apple iPhone/iPod [US] (November 4, 2010) "Capcom Arcade [Model 397347348]"[CR]

game.name: 1941: Counter Attack (Japan)
game.plot: 1941 - Counter Attack (c) 1990 Capcom. [CR]A vertically scrolling shoot'em up.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the Capcom "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board ID: 89625B-1[CR]Players: 2[CR]Control: 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons: 2[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]1941 was released in February 1990 in the Japanese arcades as the 7th CP-S release. It is the first Shoot'em Up to add +1 to the score when a continue is used.[CR]Player 1 uses a P-38 Lightning and Player 2 uses a Mosquito B Mk.IV.[CR]Known Export release: "1941 - Counter Attack [B-Board 89624B-3]".[CR]Here is all the official bosses names : [CR]* Stage 1 - Leviathan [CR]* Stage 2 - Bismarck [CR]* Stage 3 - V3Rocket [CR]* Stage 4 - Krote [CR]* Stage 5 - Leviathan [CR]* Stage 6 - Gotha [CR]Historical inaccuracies - V3Rocket : The real V3 was a Super Gun, not a rocket. Furthermore, 'V-weapons' would not appear until "1944 - The Loop Master". [CR]Default high-score table : [CR]1ST 30000 CAP [CR]2ND 29000 COM [CR]3RD 28000 CAP [CR]4TH 27000 COM [CR]5TH 26000 j01 [CR]Soundtrack album releases:[CR]Final Fight : G.S.M. Capcom 3 (PCCB-00030) (May 21, 1990) [Pony Canyon / Scitron][CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* How to Play:[CR]Control airplane with 8-way joystick.[CR]Attack with button A.[CR]Somersault & Mega-Crash with Button B.[CR]Power Blast: If the A button is held down, energy will be stored up, so that a power blast is fired when the button is released.[CR]* Hint: Your airplane doesn't lose energy when it collides with cliff-walls, buildings etc. Instead it will rotate a bit after such collisions. That means you can tumble up and down these obstacles (keep on colliding), and if you keep shooting, your shots will go in all directions. This way you can clear up a lot of enemies when you are under pressure (while rolling you are invincible).[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. 1942 (1984) [CR]2. 1943 - Midway Kaisen (1987) [CR]3. 1943 Kai - Midway Kaisen (1988) [CR]4. 1941 - Counter Attack [B-Board 89625B-1] (1990) [CR]5. 19XX - The War Against Destiny [Green Board] (1995) [CR]6. 1944 - The Loop Master [Green Board] (2000)[CR]7. 1942 - Joint Strike (2008, PSN/XBLA)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Rekite[CR]Object designers : Shinji Sakashita (Sakashita Thing), Yokota Yokozo, Terukun, Kuribow[CR]Scroll designers : Sadakichi, Marilyn Higuchi, Yuki, Kintarou, Harusan[CR]Character support : Akira Yasuda (Akiman)[CR]Character coordinator : Rekite[CR]Character effects : Yokota Yokozo[CR]Sound composer : Hifumi[CR]Programmers : Makkow, Babel-2, Dome[CR]Game analysers : Akira Nishitani (Nin), Doda Nda Uda[CR]Director : Yoshiki Okamoto (Kihaji Okamoto)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of Japanese ports. For a list of ports released outside Japan, please see the export version entry, "1941 - Counter Attack [B-Board 89624B-3]". [CR]* Consoles : [CR]NEC SuperGrafx [JP] (August 22, 1991) "1941 - Counter Attack [Model HC91048]"[CR]

game.name: Three Wonders (World 910520)
game.plot: Three Wonders (c) 1991 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Export releases. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Wonder 3 [B-Board 89625B-1]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board #: 89624B-3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]These Export versions have some differences to the original Japanese version:[CR]* The action game is called 'Midnight Wanderers' instead 'Roosters'.[CR]* Midnight Wanderers is slightly easier in a few ways: the stage 1 mid-boss has a lower rate of fire, the stage 1 end-boss is less aggressive by shooting more and punching less.[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released outside Japan. For Japanese ports, please see the original Japanese version entry; "Wonder 3 [B-Board 89625B-1]". game.name: Area 88 (Japan)
game.plot: Area 88 (c) 1989 Capcom.[CR]Area 88 is a superb sideways scrolling shoot-em-up in which the players chooses from 3 jet fighters: an A-10 Thunderbolt, a F-14 tomcat and an F-20 tiger Shark - and must battle their way through 10 enemy-packed levels (plus an extra bonus stage).[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board ID: 88622B-3[CR]Players: 2[CR]Control: 8-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons: 2[CR]=> [1] Fire, [2] Special[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Area 88 was originally released in August 1989 in Japan. It was known there as the 6th video game made for the CP System.[CR]Area 88 is based on a Japanese Manga series published from 1979 to 1986. It was created by Kaoru Shintani and tells the story of Shin Kazawa, a mercenary fighter pilot training for the Area 88 air force base. The manga was very popular in Japan and was even adapted into at least three OVAs in 1985 and a twelve episode animation series in 2005.[CR]Known Export releases:[CR]"U.N. Squadron [B-Board 89624B-2]"[CR]It was re-released in 1991 as "Area 88 [B-Board 91634B-2]".[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Area 88 - PCCB-00018) on January 21, 1989.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* More Money : if you start a 2-player game at the same time, each one will be credited 3000 dollars. On the other hand, if the second player arrives afterwards, he will have 12000 dollars (you have just gained 9000 dollars).[CR]* Hidden Mission : there are several methods to play this mission, here is one : Beat the Mission 3 (The Forest Fortress) by destroying the heart of the fortress on the first blow (1st passage).[CR]* Various Little Ending Animations : at the ending screen (presented by Capcom), various little animations are shown dependent on how much Mechs were recovered, or if the Unicorn was recovered...[CR]Mission 3, Forest Fortress :[CR]Unicorn (+ a shield) - Destroy all trees without forgetting from the very start of the level to destroy the 1st tree on the left. The unicorn will appear spontaneously in front of the fortress.[CR]Yashichi - Destroy the latest turret of the fortress, Yashichi is just on the right in bottom of the fire turret. [CR]Mission 4, The Carrier :[CR]Mech (1000 pts) - Just behind the 5th rock, on the ground level, a Mech which agitates a flag will appear.[CR]Mission 5, Bomber called Bayson :[CR]Mech (+ a T.Laser) - You must destroy the 39 rocks to see a Mech appear with a knife.[CR]Mission 6, Missile Launcher :[CR]Mech (10000 pts) - When the way separates in 2 ways, take the top while shooting at the base from the 1st pillar made of rock, a Mech will appear.[CR]Mission 8, Battleship called Minks :[CR]Mech (1000 pts) - After the 2 boats come from the left, place yourself at the top of the screen and shoot until a Mech with a rifle falls into water.[CR]Yashichi - At the middle of the Battleship, we have a red turret, destroy it to release Yashichi. [CR]Mission 9, The Arsenal :[CR]Mech (1000 pts) - Behind the second building, a Mech with an umbrella hides.[CR]Special Mission :[CR]Mech (10000 pts) - An airliner will go down in the middle from the screen, then go up. Go to the left of the screen. When the plane starts to go down again, shoot until you see appearing the Mech overlapping a rocket at the bottom right of the screen.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Area 88 [CP-S No. 06] (1989)[CR]2. U.S. Navy [CP-S No. 12] (1990)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Mako P, Parazoll Shono, Noritaka Funamizu (Poo)[CR]Direction : Yoshiki Okamoto (Kihaji Okamoto)[CR]Character designers : Manbou Shintan, Gokkun Kuratani, Rekite, Unicorn Mayumi, Traveller Kuramoyan, Holiday Kakkun, Haru San, Konomi (Powerful Konomi), Fukumoyan, Femme Hana[CR]Music composer : Chan Chakorin[CR]Hard design : Kucchan[CR]Programmers : Blbon, Takako[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Only Japanese releases are listed here. For ports released outside Japan, refer to the Export version entry; "U.N. Squadron [B-Board 89624B-2]".[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (July 26, 1991) "Area 88 [Model SHVC-E8]"[CR]

game.name: Captain Commando (Japan 910928)
game.plot: Captain Commando (c) 1991 Capcom Company, Limited. [CR]In this beat'em up, Captain Commando and his three faithful companions travel through various locales on their way to confront the evil Scumocide![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board #: 91634B-2[CR]Players: Up to 4 simultaneously[CR]Control per player: 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons per player: 2[CR]=> [1] Attack, [2] Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Captain Commando was released in November 1991 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 17th video game made for the CP-S system.[CR]CAPtain COMmando = CAPCOM [CR]The stages of the game takes place in "Final Fight"'s Metro City, but in the year 2026. [CR]Captain Commando is Capcom's own homage to classic American sci-fi shows and magazines and the work of artists like Frank R. Paul. It was not the only game, though; "Battle Circuit" is even a better example of Capcom's enthusiasm for this stuff. [CR]Each of the player's button on the dedicated 4-player cabinet uses a unique two-in-one play action button design : two large half circle buttons (red & blue) placed straight side by straight side to form one big circle, thus making two buttons look like one big button cut in half vertically. [CR]Mack the Knife's name is based on a song made popular in the mid 1950's by Louis Armstrong, and later by Bobby Darin. [CR]Ginzu the ninja's name comes from the ginzu kitchen knives which were introduced in the 1970's which were made famous by its TV advertising campaign. [CR]Sho (Ginzu the ninja's Japanese name) is probably based on Sho Kosugi who is a Japanese actor who is known for his portrayals of ninjas in various movies in the 1980's. [CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Captain Commando : G.S.M. Capcom 5 - PCCB-00083) on March 21, 1992.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Akira Yasuda (Akiman), Junichi Ohno (Ohno)[CR]Character Designers : Kurisan, Ouji, Eripyon. N, Mattian, Q, Mayo, Ykaru M.[CR]Scroll Designers : Koi, Konomi (Powerful Konomi), Sui, Buppo, Go[CR]Programmers : Y. Egawa, Yokoyama, T. Ueno, Yoshizumi[CR]Sound : Masaki Izutani (T. Yomage)[CR]Sound-Sub : Syun Nishigaki (Syun)[CR]Special Thanks : James Goddard (DJames), Scott, Tetsu, Akira Nishitani (Nin)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in Japan only. To see non-Japanese ports, please see the Export version entry; "Captain Commando [B-Board 91635B-2]".[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (March 17, 1995) "Captain Commando [Model SHVC-QM]"[CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (September 17, 1998) "Captain Commando [Model SLPS-01567]" by New, Inc.[CR]

game.name: Captain Commando (World 911014)
game.plot: Captain Commando (c) 1991 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Export release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "U.S. Navy [B-Board 89625B-1]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board ID: 89624B-3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]The guy who looks like Sean Connery looks even more like Sean Connery in the Japanese release of the game than in the Export versions (graphic changed). Maybe in the hope to avoid license problems in the U.S. ?[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. U.N. Squadron [CP-S No. 06] (1989) [CR]2. Carrier Airwing [CP-S No. 12] (1990)[CR]

game.name: U.S. Navy (Japan 901012)
game.plot: U.S. Navy (c) 1990 Capcom.[CR]A solid and hugely playable sequel to 1989's superb sideways scrolling shoot-em-up, Area 88. As with the original, players chose any one of three different jet fighters and battle their way through ten enemy-packed stages. Another idea carried over from Area 88 is the end-of-level shop, which allows players to buy weapon and shield upgrades for their jet fighter.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware[CR]B-Board ID: 89625B-1[CR]Players: Up to 2[CR]Control per player: 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons per player: 2[CR]=> [1] Shoot, [2] Special Weapon[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]U.S. Navy was released in October 1990 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 12th video game made for the CP-S system.[CR]Known export release: "Carrier Airwing [B-Board 89624B-3]"[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Street Fighter II : G.S.M. Capcom 4 - PCCB-00056) on March 21, 1991.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Real Ending : beat the game in one credit.[CR]* Secret items :[CR]Mission 2 :[CR]White Mech (10000 pts) - After the large helicopter and when the suspended road finished, go up quickly and shoot.[CR]Mission 3 :[CR]Rabbit (20000 pts) - Shoot on the 9th tree or release a bomb.[CR]Cow (10000 pts) - Destroy the ground monticule in top of the hill right after the 9th tree (you can make turns to the cow by shooting on).[CR]Man (6000 pts) - Shoot between the base of the mountain and the cuirassier.[CR]Mission 6 :[CR]Snowman (4000 pts) - Shoot at the base of the 4th iceberg.[CR]Mission 7 :[CR]Small bear (8000 pts) - Towards the end of the level, shoot at the middle of the 1st gray mountain, just before the 1st volcano.[CR]Mission 8 :[CR]Mech with a flag (20000 pts) - Release a bomb behind the second house.[CR]Mission 9 :[CR]Red Mech (10000 pts) - Shoot at the base of the fortress wall.[CR]Yashichi - Destroy the red turret located on a footbridge.[CR]Mission 10 :[CR]Yashichi - Destroy the red turret located at the top of the engines.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Area 88 [CP-S No. 06] (1989)[CR]2. U.S. Navy [CP-S No. 12] (1990)[CR]

It was known there as the 10th video game made for the CP System.[CR]The game was known outside Japan as "Mega Twins [B-Board 89624B-3]".[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game Designer : Bully Duck[CR]Directors : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Yoshiki Okamoto (Kihaji Okamoto)[CR]Object Designers : Manbou, Ikusan Z, Unicorn Mayumi[CR]Scroll Designers : Zummy, Ziggy (Zummy & Ziggy)[CR]Hard Designer : Kuccan[CR]Programmers : Blbon, Meijin, Yuki Saiko[CR]Spacial Thanks : Ozzy, Kame, Satochin, Genie[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Mega Drive [JP] (1993) "Chiki Chiki Boys [Model G-4083]" [CR]PC-Engine CD-ROM² [JP] (July 15, 1994) "Chiki Chiki Boys [Model NAPR-1033]"[CR]

game.name: Adventure Quiz Capcom World 2 (Japan 920611)
game.plot: Capcom World 2 - Adventure Quiz (c) 1992 Capcom.[CR]A Japanese quiz game.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board # 89625B-1[CR]# of Players: Up to 2[CR]# of Buttons (per player): 4[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Capcom World 2 was released in June 1992 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 20th video game made for the CP-S system. The game was never exported outside Japan.[CR]This game features a multitude of characters from several Capcom games! Here they are listed by source game title :[CR]* Captain Commando: Captain Commando, Baby Head (Baby Commando), Mack the Knife (Mummy Commando), Ginzu the Ninja (Ninja Commando), Carol, Doppel, Dr.T.W. (with the Monster), Marbin, Scumocide and Wooky (with a Robot).[CR]* Final Fight: Cody, Guy, Haggar, Abigail, Edi E., Poison, Rolento and Sodom.[CR]* Forgotten Worlds: Unknown Soldier, Dust Dragon and the girl from the shop.[CR]* The King of Dragons: Cleric, Dwarf, Elf, Fighter, Wizard and Gildiss (the final boss).[CR]* Knights of the Round: Arthur, Lancelot, Perceval, Garibaldi (or Arlon?) and Scorn.[CR]* Magic Sword: Lizardman, Theif, Drokmar, Quimyra and several unnamed characters (player one, the cloak and dagger baddie, the skull wizard baddie and the dragon).[CR]* Mega Man III: Megaman, Dr. Light, Dr. Wily, Protoman, Geminiman, Hardman, Shadowman, Snakeman, Hammer Joe and Mon King.[CR]* Street Fighter II: Blanka, Chun Li, Dhalsim, E. Honda, Guile, Ken, Ryu and Zangief.[CR]* Strider Hiryu: Itself[CR]* Three Wonders: Gaia, Laru (the one with the sword) and an unnamed rabbit (player one from the 'Don't Pull' segment).[CR]Two of the game's characters (Pure & Fur) appear as assist characters in "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes".[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Capcom World - Adventure Quiz (1989)[CR]2. Capcom World 2 - Adventure Quiz [B-Board 89625B-1] (1992)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Character designers : Yamachan, Okame, Kitasan, M. Okazaki, Nakatsuka, Ban, Hkn, E. Shida[CR]Programmers : M. Kobayashi, Pon, Hero Hero, H.M.D.[CR]Music & sound : Syun Nishigaki (SYUN)[CR]Planners : C. Kanemitsu, Hiratou K-Suke, K. Nishikawa, E. Shida[CR]

game.name: Daimakaimura (Japan)
game.plot: 大魔界村 (c) 1988 Capcom.[CR](Daimakaimura)[CR]Three years have passed since the events of "Makaimura" and Arthur the knight once again finds himself battling against the hideous creatures of Demon World. The demons have now seized the kingdom and Arthur returns home to witness the castle's lone survivor, his beloved Gunievere, murdered by the king of the demons, Lucifer. Arthur once again embarks on a one-man quest to destroy the demonic invaders and save Gunievere's mortal soul. [CR]Game-play is of a very similar vein to that of "Makaimura" - the classic run, jump and shoot action remains intact. Daimakaimura is, however, even more difficult than its already demanding predecessor. Arthur now has access to several new power-ups to aid him on his daunting quest, such as 'Golden Armour' which gives Arthur greater protection from the demons. Additionally, unlike "Makaimura", Arthur can now fire his weapons upwards instead of just left or right and, while jumping, can fire beneath him as well. [CR]The graphics in Daimakaimura are predictably far superior to those of its 1985 prequel, with highly imaginative level design and superbly-drawn, smoothly animated enemies all adding to the game's superb Gothic feel.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware[CR]B-Board #: 88622B-2[CR]B-Board PALs: DM22A | LWIO[CR]C-Board #: 88622-C-1 (no PALs)[CR]CPS-B #: CPS-B-01 DL-0411-10001[CR]Players: 2 (Alternatively)[CR]Control: 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons: 2[CR]=> [1] Fire, [2] Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Daimakaimura was originally released in December 1988 in the Japanese arcades. The game was known as the second video game made for the CPS1 system. It was then released outside Japan as "Ghouls'n Ghosts [B-Board 88620B-2]".[CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Great Demon World village'.[CR]A re-edition was released as "Daimakaimura [B-Board 91634B-2]" in Japan only.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Daimakaimura : G.S.M. Capcom 1 - D28B-0011) on January 11, 1989.[CR]Suleputer released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Makaimura Music Collection - CPCA-10128~34) on December 28, 2005 containing music from the original arcade and Sega Mega Drive series.[CR][B]Scoring[/B][CR]Skeleton Murderer : 100 points [CR]The Magician : 100 points [CR]Vulture : 200 points [CR]Skull Flower : 100 points [CR]Skull : 100 points [CR]Tornado Weasel : 200 points [CR]Giant Earthworm : 200 points [CR]Pig Ogre : 500 points [CR]Shielder (Level 1 boss) : 5,000 points [CR]Rock Turtle : 200 points [CR]Insect Goblin : 100 points [CR]Red Arremer King : 500 points [CR]Fire Bat : 100 points [CR]Eyeball Plant : 500 points [CR]Cerberus (Level 2 boss) : 5,000 points [CR]Flying Goblin : 100 points [CR]Mud Armor : 500 points [CR]Blowfish Ghoul : 100 points [CR]Gassuto (Level 3 boss) : 5,000 points [CR]Tree Golem : 500 points [CR]Armored Worm : 300 points [CR]Goblin Hand : 300 points [CR]Water Worm : 200 points [CR]Hurricane Eye (small) : 500 points [CR]Ghoul Snake : 500 points [CR]Ohme (Level 4 boss) : 5,000 points [CR]Heart of Ohme : 100 points [CR]Ohme Larva : 100 points [CR]Dragon Skeleton : 200 points [CR]Satan : 1,000 points [CR]Headless Golem : 1,000 points [CR]Beelzebub (Level 5 boss) : 5,000 points [CR]Lucifer (Final boss) : 10,000 points [CR]Citizen Doll : this item gives you 200 extra points. [CR]Knight Doll : this item gives you 500 extra points.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Makaimura (1985, Arcade)[CR]2. Daimakaimura [B-Board 88622B-2] (1988, Arcade)[CR]3. Chou Makaimura [Model SHVC-CM] (1991, Super Famicom)[CR]4. Arthur to Astaroth - Nazo-Makaimura - Incredible Toons (1996, PlayStation)[CR]5. Maximo (2001, PS2)[CR]6. Makai Eiyuuki Maximo - Machine Monster no Yabou (2003, PS2)[CR]7. Goku Makaimura (2006, PSP)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game designers : Tokuro Fujiwara, S. Yoshimoto, H. Yamamoto[CR]Programmers : Hiroshi Koike, Masatsugu Shinoara, Shinichi Ueyama[CR]Music by : Tamayo Kawamoto[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports release in Japan only. To see ports released in other regions, please see the export version entry; "Ghouls'n Ghosts [B-Board 88620B-2]"[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Mega Drive [JP] (August 3, 1989) "Daimakaimura [Model G-4013]" [CR]NEC SuperGrafx [JP] (July 27, 1990) "Daimakaimura [Model NAPH-1008]" [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (September 23, 1998) "Capcom Generation Dai 2 Shou Makai to Kishi [Model T-1233G]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (September 23, 1998) "Capcom Generation Dai 2 Shou Makai to Kishi [Model SLPS-01585]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (March 2, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model SLPM-66317]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 3 [PSN] [JP] (February 19, 2013) "Capcom Arcade Cabinet [Model NPJB-00210]"[CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Sony PSP [JP] (September 7, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model ULJM-05104]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]Sharp X68000 [JP] (1994)[CR]

game.name: Cadillacs: Kyouryuu Shin Seiki (Japan 930201)
game.plot: Cadillacs Kyouryuu Shin Seiki (c) 1993 Capcom.[CR]In this 2-D side-scrolling beat'em up, four earth-minded heroes attempt to stop poachers from harming the dinosaur population. Each character has his or her special strengths and abilities.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board #: 91634B[CR]# of Players: Up to 3 simultaneous.[CR]Type of controls (per player): 8-way joystick[CR]# of Buttons (per player): 2[CR]=> [1] Attack, [2] Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Cadillacs Kyouryuu Shin Seiki was released in February 1993 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 25th video game made for the CP-S system.[CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Cadillacs New Dinosaur Century'.[CR]This game is very famous by the name "Mustapha's game" (the main character of the game) in Asia.[CR]Characters based upon the comic 'Xenozoic Tales' created in the late eighties by Mark Schultz.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Tenchi Wo Kurau II : G.S.M. Capcom 7 - PCCB-00133) on August 20, 1993.[CR]Exported as "Cadillacs and Dinosaurs [B-Board 91635B-2]".[CR]There is also an unofficial Chinese version known as "Dinosaur Hunter".[CR]There is a modified version of this game (hack?), in which certain gun(s) have unlimited ammo.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]On the 2nd and 5th stages, there appears a large dinosaur called a Shivat that's sleeping when first encountered. Try to keep the human enemies from whacking them to wake them up. While the Shivats do attack the enemies, they can also cause trouble (and injuries) for the players.[CR]There are also some pterodactyl-like flying creatures that need to be struck by jumping to reach them. Whenever you drain the energy from any menacing dinosaurs, they slightly change color, then become harmless.[CR]On the 3rd stage, where you're driving Jack's Cadillac, try to dodge the grenades thrown by the stage's motorcycle-riding boss, Hogg, while crashing into him with the car. If you're good at this, you should be able to at least reduce his energy to the yellow level, the lowest for the enemies.[CR]On the 6th stage, there's 2 points at where you need to be careful not to be stomped on by the legs of a brontosaurus. But, try to lure some of the other enemies underneath them instead![CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planning : DA., Hattari, JRA[CR]Object GFX : Kurisan, Jun Matsumura (Jun), Matano, Ss, Shisui, Kinmon, The Who[CR]Scroll GFX : Nissui, Konomi, Ohnicchan, Bentobucho[CR]Programmers : Yuki Saiko, Cky Gi-u, T. Uragoro, Some-P[CR]Music : Isao Abe (Piro2 Oyaji), Syun Nishigaki (Syun), Kiyo[CR]Sound : Toshio Kajino (Toshi Bull), Nobuhiro Oouchi (Nobu. Oouchi)[CR]Assists : Kitasan, Yokozo, Daniel, Inukichi, Ban, Jirou, Kurata-N, Hanisawa[CR]AD-Design : Sho, Tom, Sensei[CR]USA Support : James Goddard (DJames.)[CR]Many Thanks : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Akira Nishitani (Nin), Hore Hore, Alex Jimenez, Super Joe[CR]

game.name: Tenchi wo Kurau (Japan)
game.plot: 天地を喰らう (c) 1989 Capcom.[CR](Tenchi wo Kurau)[CR]Tenchi wo Kurau is a 1 or 2-player game where you play one of four Chinese heroes on horseback and try to kill hordes of enemies. This game always scrolls to the right. [CR]The 1st button will make you face left and swing your weapon, the 2nd button will make you face right and swing your weapon, while the 3rd button will let you use magic. You can also add coins any time to increase your vitality.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Capcom Play System hardware (CPS) [CR]B-Board ID: 88622B-3[CR]Players: Up to 2. [CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 3 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Tenchi wo Kurau was released in April 1989 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 4th video game made for the CP-S system. It is known outside Japan as "Dynasty Wars".[CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Heaven and Earth Recieving Blows'.[CR]Known Re-releases: "Tenchi wo Kurau [B-Board 91634B-2]"[CR]Known Export releases: "Dynasty Wars [B-Board 88622B-3]"[CR]The background story and all characters are based on factual history : the Period of Three Kingdoms after the 'Hen' Dynasty in China. Character designs were based on a popular Japanese comic called 'Destruction of Heaven and Earth'. [CR]The Tenchi wo Kurau series is based on the Chinese tale best known as Romance of the Three Kingdoms. [CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Strider Hiryu : G.S.M. Capcom 2 - D25B1001) on May 21, 1989.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Tenchi wo Kurau [B-Board 88622B-3] (1989)[CR]2. Tenchi wo Kurau II - Sekiheki no Tatakai [B-Board 91634B-2] (1992)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Yoshiki Okamoto (Kihaji Okamoto)[CR]Game designers : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), S. Sato, K. Kataoka[CR]Programmers : Y. Mutsunobu, M. Kobayashi, Y. Tsunasaki[CR]Obj Designers : Kurichan, Y. Tamago, M. Tanabe, M. Matsuura, Shinji Sakashita[CR]Scr Designers : Fukumoyan, M. Konishi, M. Miyao, K. Koizumi[CR]Sound music : Manami Goto[CR]Illustration : S. Shintani[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]NEC PC-Engine [JP] (1991) [CR]NEC PC-Engine Super CD-ROM² [JP] (June 17, 1994) [Model NAPR1030] [CR]Nintendo Game Boy [JP] (April 22, 1994) [Model DMG-ETJ][CR]

game.name: Final Fight (Japan)
game.plot: Final Fight (c) 1989 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Jessica, the daughter of the city Mayor Mike Haggar has been kidnapped by the evil 'Mad Gear' gang. Set in the fictional Metro City, Haggar rounds up two of his closest friends, Guy and Cody, and sets out to battle Mad Gear's gang members and ultimately rescue his daughter.[CR]1 or 2 players choose to play as either Guy, Cody or Haggar in this superb, sideways scrolling beat-em-up. As well as the standard punch and kick moves, each character also has a special attack. This move is powerful enough to fell several enemies at once, but with the trade-off that each time a special attack is executed, some of the player's energy is lost. Energy levels can be replenished by finding the food that lies hidden in certain crates and barrels. Some of the Mad Gear gang members will drop a weapon when they are felled. These weapons can then be picked up and used by the players.[CR]After the benchmark-setting "Double Dragon", released by Technos in 1987, Final Fight would become the standard-bearer of the scrolling beat-em-up genre. Featuring a large variety of distinctive, well animated characters moving through colorful and detailed backgrounds, and with a control system that is as intuitive as it is complex, Final Fight is still considered to be the finest example of its kind.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board ID: 88622B-3[CR]Players: Up to 2 simultaneously.[CR]Control per player: 8-way joystick.[CR]Buttons per player: 3.[CR]=> [1] Attack, [2] Jump, [3] Release (when grabbed by enemies).[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Final Fight was released in December 1989 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 8th video game made for the CP System.[CR]This game was originally billed as the sequel to "Street Fighter" and was to be called "Street Fighter '89". While the game had become a major hit in its own right, Capcom decided to change the name to "Final Fight" and save the "Street Fighter" name for another game, 2 years later. [CR]Guy's name is written with the kanji meaning 'victory song'. The character of Guy has been allegedly inspired by the lead singer of the post hardcore group Fugazi, Guy Picciotto. [CR]The enemy character, Andore, and all of his relatives (Andore Jr., Uncle Andore, Father Andore and Grandfather Andore) are Capcom's homage to the now late WWF Champion, Andre Rene Roussimoff, better known as 'Andre the Giant'. [CR]Two other Mad Gear characters, Axl and Slash, are parodies of the lead singer and guitarist respectively from American rock band, 'Guns N' Roses'. [CR]Poison is taken from the glam rock group of the '80s, in which the singer used to wear a similar hat to the female character in the game. The character Poison is actually a male transvestite and so is Roxy (although a translation error in the Capcom Classics Collection character profiles refers to Roxy as a female). [CR]Abigail is a King Diamond album, whose singer (King Diamond) resembles the character in the game. [CR]Sodom is a famous German thrash metal band founded in the eighties. [CR]The enemy character 'Two P' appears in "Forgotten Worlds" as the second player ('Two P' for 2P, 'Player 2').[CR]The game shares a similar plot with the 1984 movie 'Streets of Fire' directed by Walter Hill. Starring : Michael Paré, Diane Lane, Rick Moranis and Willem Dafoe. Here's a list of the things the movie and the game have in common (Warning! Contains movie spoilers) : [CR]1) The main character played by Michael Paré is named 'Tom Cody' and resembles the game character. Wears jeans and a white shirt at some points during the movie. [CR]2) The city is plagued by gangs and a motorcycle gang kidnaps Cody's Ex girlfriend. [CR]3) The cop that arranges a meeting between Cody and the Gang's boss is nothing other than a corrupted cop by the name of 'Ed Price', the only Cop in the game is called 'Eddie'. [CR]4) The city has an old and trashed look similar to the game. [CR]5) At the end of the movie, Cody leaves the girl just like in the game. Only this time there is no 'Guy' to stop him from leaving (see Final Fight ending sequence)[CR]Known re-release: "Final Fight [B-Board 89625B-1]"[CR]Known Export release: "Final Fight [B-Board 89624B-3]"[CR]A bootleg of this game is known as "Final Crash". [CR]Before the release of "Final Fight", Capcom released a vertically scrolling driving/shoot-em-up called "Mad Gear". [CR]Pony Canyon/Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Final Fight : G.S.M. Capcom 3 - PCCB-00030) on May 21, 1990.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]First revision:[CR]* No Build Date screen.[CR]Second revision:[CR]* Buid Date screen added.[CR]* Build date: 900112[CR]Third revision:[CR]* Build date: 900305[CR]Fourth revision:[CR]* Build date: 900613[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* At the front of the train of Level 2, stand on the barrel and let the clock get to about 45. You will skip the section without defeating the Mad Gear guys. [CR]* Special Endings : Finish the game without having to continue to see an additional credit sequence (meet the staff). [CR]* Hidden Stuff : [CR]Gaining extra points : To gain jewels and other high points items from breakable stuff like barrels, dustbins. Execute the jump+down attack move. (Cody - headbutt, Guy - Elbow). When doing the move, rapidly jag controller left to right. Usually, jewels will appear instead of other cheap things. [CR]Crewing Gum : When fighting Eddie B. (Cop), you will notice that he spit out a wad of gum. That thing will give you about half a life if you pick it up. [CR]Last Boss : Cody is able to punch away the bolts that the last boss fires. No other character can do it. [CR]Off the wall attack : Besides doing the normal off the wall flying kick, you can change it into a flying elbow drop by doing down+attack. [CR]Hidden Gems : On the way to the last boss, there is a stage when there are some pillars. Located at the bottom of each pillar are gems. Make sure you get them. [CR]* Super Combo : This super combo can be easily executed with Cody or Guy, but it's a bit tougher with Haggar. To begin, initiate a punching combo (press attack, attack, attack for Cody or Guy) or (attack, attack for Haggar.) While you're pressing these buttons, hold the D-pad AWAY from your enemy. Before you do your final ending combo blow, you will throw the enemy, delivering massive damage! [CR]Note : You can also start this combo with a jumping knee (jump and hold down, press attack) to deal even more damage! (This will not work for Haggar). [CR]There's an easier way to do this: simply pull the joystick down while punching and the combo will finish throwing the enemy. [CR]* Cody is the only character who can attack with a knife without throwing it. Press Attack while standing next to an enemy to stab them.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Final Fight [B-Board 88622B-3] (1989, Arcade) [CR]2. Final Fight 2 [Model SHVC-F2] (1993, Super Famicom) [CR]3. Mighty Final Fight (1993, Famicom) [CR]4. Final Fight Tough [Model SHVC-AFZJ-JPN] (1995, Super Famicom) [CR]5. Final Fight Revenge (1999, Arcade) [CR]6. Final Fight - Streetwise (2006, PS2/XBOX)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planner : Pon G, Akira Nishitani (Nin), Akira Yasuda (Akiman)[CR]Programmers : Kiyomi Kaneko (Kanekon), Shin., Tomiyan, Yokoyan[CR]Character designers : S.Y., Tissue, Prince[CR]Backgrounds designers : Mikman, Okachan, Fukumary, Nissui[CR]Music : Yoshihiro Sakaguchi (Youki Chan's papa)[CR]Special thanks : CBX, Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Chin, Yamachan[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of Japanese ports. To see ports released in other regions, please see the export version entry; "Final Fight [B-Board 89624B-3]".[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (December 21, 1990) "Final Fight [Model SHVC-FT]" [CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (March 20, 1992) "Final Fight Guy [Model SHVC-FY]" [CR]Sega Mega CD [JP] (April 2, 1993) "Final Fight CD [Model G-6013]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (March 2, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model SLPM-66317]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Advance [JP] (May 25, 2001) "Final Fight One [Model AGB-AFFJ-JPN]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]Sharp X68000 [JP] (July 17, 1992)[CR]

game.name: Street Smart / Final Fight (Japan, hack)
game.plot: Final Fight (c) 199? Unknown [China][CR]A Chinese hack of Final Fight where you can select and play enemies![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]This pirate hack uses an official Japanese B-Board 91634B-2. The EPROMS have been modified. The Board uses a GAL instead of the classic PAL. There is no ROM check at the start and no logo Capcom, instead there is a chinese text. The game intro is in English.[CR]

game.name: Final Fight (USA, set 1)
game.plot: Final Fight (c) 1990 Capcom USA, Incorporated.[CR]Export release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, see the original Japanese release entry; "Final Fight [B-Board 88622B-3]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board ID: 89624B-3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]The original Japanese version had a scene that shows Jessica in underwear on the TV in the abstract mode. game.name: Ghouls'n Ghosts (World)
game.plot: Ghouls'n Ghosts (c) 1988 Capcom.[CR]Export release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Daimakaimura [B-Board 88622B-2]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware[CR]B-Board ID 88620B-2[CR]B-Board PALs: DM620[CR]CPS-B #: CPS-B-01 DL-0411-10001[CR]There is no C-Board on these Export versions, contrary to the original Japanese release.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Ghouls'n Ghosts was released in December 1988 in arcades outside of Japan. It is known in Japan as "Daimakaimura".[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]Debug features (US VERSION ONLY, it doesn't work on the original Japanese version) : [CR]How to activate the debug features.[CR]1) Set "Game Mode" Dip Switch to "Game".[CR]2) Set both "Coin A" and "Coin B" Dip Switches to 1C_1C.[CR]3) Reset the game.[CR]4) Insert a coin.[CR]5) Set "Game Mode" Dip Switch to "Test".[CR]6) Set the debug Dip Switches to what you want.[CR]7) Start a 1 player game.[CR]Some debug features :[CR]- "Armor on New Life" is effective at the begining of a new life. Note that even when you start without armor, you need to be hit twice.[CR]- "Starting Weapon" is effective only when you start a new game or when you continue play.[CR]- "Starting Level" is effective only when you start a new game (you must NOT continue play !).[CR]- "Slow Motion" and "Invulnerability" can be changed at any time.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Ghosts'n Goblins (1985, Arcade)[CR]2. Ghouls'n Ghosts [B-Board 88620B-2] (1988, Arcade)[CR]3. Super Ghouls'n Ghosts [Model SNS-CM-USA] (1991, SNES)[CR]4. Maximo - Ghosts to Glory (2002, PS2)[CR]5. Maximo vs. Army of Zin (2004, PS2)[CR]6. Ultimate Ghosts'n Goblins (2006, PSP)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of all ports excluding Japanese ones. To see Japanese ports, please see the original Japanese version entry; "Daimakaimura [B-Board 88622B-2]".[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Genesis [US] (1989) [CR]Sega Mega Drive [BR] (1990) by Tec Toy [CR]Sega Mega Drive [KO] (1990) "Daemagyecheon [Model GM-5008-JM]" [CR]Sega Master System [US] [EU] (1990) "Ghouls'n Ghosts [Model 7055]" [CR]Sega Master System [BR] (1990) by Tec Toy [CR]Sega Mega Drive [EU] (November 30, 1990) [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (September 3, 1999) "Capcom Generations 2 - Chronicles of Arthur [Capcom Generations Disc 2] [Model SLES-11881]" [CR]Microsoft XBOX [US] (September 27, 2005) "Capcom Classics Collection" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (September 27, 2005) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model SLUS-21316]" [CR]Microsoft XBOX [EU] (November 18, 2005) "Capcom Classics Collection" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (November 18, 2005) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model SLES-53661]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Sony PSP [US] (October 24, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Reloaded [Model ULUS-10134]" [CR]Sony PSP [EU] (November 10, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Reloaded [Model ULES-00377]" [CR]Sony PSP [AU] (November 16, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Reloaded" [CR]* Computers : [CR]Sinclair ZX Spectrum [EU] (1989) [CR]Commodore C64 [US] [EU] (1989) [CR]Atari ST [EU] (1989) [CR]Amstrad CPC [EU] (1989) [CR]Commodore Amiga [US] (1989) "Ghouls 'n' Ghosts"[CR]Commodore Amiga [US] (1991) "Ghouls 'n' Ghosts & Venus the Flytrap [Chart Attack]"[CR]Commodore Amiga [US] (199?) "Ghouls 'n' Ghosts [Platinum]"[CR]Amstrad CPC [EU] (1990) "Coin-Op Hits II"[CR]Amstrad CPC [EU] (1991) "Capcom Collection" [CR]Atari ST [EU] (1991) "Capcom Collection" [CR]Commodore C64 [EU] (1991) "Capcom Collection" [CR]Commodore Amiga [EU] (1991) "Capcom Collection" [CR]Sinclair ZX Spectrum [EU] (1991) "Capcom Collection" [CR]* Others : [CR]Street Fighter II' Special Champion Edition Plug 'n Play TV Game [US] (2004) by Radica Games : Genesis version included as a bonus.[CR]Apple iPhone/iPod [US] (November 4, 2010) "Capcom Arcade [Model 397347348]"[CR]

game.name: Knights of the Round (Japan 911127, B-Board 89625B-1)
game.plot: Knights of the Round (c) 1991 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]King Arthur, Sir Lancelot and Percival slash through medieval England to save the peasants from enslavement. Featuring a level-up system which gives the fighters new weapons and armor.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board #: 89625B-1[CR]Players: Up to 3 simultaneous[CR]Control per player: 8-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons per player: 2[CR]=> [1] Attack, [2] Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Knights of the Round was released in November 1991 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 18th video game made for the CP-S system.[CR]Knights of the Round is based on the story of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table. [CR]Len Hanley holds the official record for this game with 431,450 points.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Varth : G.S.M Capcom 6 - PCCB-00110) on February 19, 1993.[CR]Known re-release: "Knights of the Round [B-Board 91634B-2]"[CR]Known Export release: "Knights of the Round [B-Board 91635B-2]"[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]Earning Extra Lives : In Stage 2, lose 1 life against boss. Beat him. When you come to the 3rd stage, don't break the barricades, just wait. First kill the Fat-Man and the Soldier. [CR]Warning : If you launch a desperation attack (attack+jump), all the effort will be lost. [CR]Then wait until the Bird Man comes run against you. Hit him with a strong strike (Push front+punch). Don't hit him while is recovering. Wait until he runs to you again and make the same. you can kill him after 3 strikes (unless with Lancelot). [CR]If you're done correctly, hit the barricade of the above, don't pick the food, try to turn apart it, and you'll get a surprise... a chess piece with 2 lives (2Up) waiting for you. [CR]If you kill the second Bird-Man in the same way, the second item in the barricade will give you 1 more level (green sceptre). [CR]If you remember, a 3rd Bird-Man gets into the castle when you break the bridge's barricade. Do the same trick with him inside, break the down barricade, break the item and you'll get one more life (1Up).[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game Designers : Boyoyon, Hachi, K. Suke, Nis 7[CR]Music Sound : Isao Abe (Oyaji)[CR]Programmers : Ayrton Tsuna !!, Hero Hero, Cky[CR]Object Designers : Ikusan Z, Tanuki, Imomushi, Jun Matsumura (Jun), Sho[CR]Scroll Designers : Fukumoyan, Pooh!, Kyochan, Marchan[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of Japanese ports. For ports released in other regions, please see the Export version entry; "Knights of the Round [B-Board 91635B-2]"[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (June 10, 1994) "Knights of the Round [Model SHVC-LO]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Sony PSP [JP] (September 7, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model ULJM-05104]"[CR]

game.name: The King of Dragons (World 910805)
game.plot: The King of Dragons (c) 1991 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]New release. For more information about the game itself, see the original Japanese release entry; "The King of Dragons [B-Board 89625B-1]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]B-Board #: 90629B-3[CR]It contains a 4-Mbit EPROM instead of 4x1-Mbits EPROMs on the original B-Board 89625B-1.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Here is a list of features found in these new revisions:[CR]* A weaver effect of character sprites at the beginning of characters selection screen.[CR]* A different sound effect is used when a character gains a level-up, enters a stage or rises again.[CR]* More difficult (more enemies).[CR]* Enemies appearance is very different from the early 'World revision' of the game (July 1991).[CR]* Cleric is less powerful than in the early 'World revision'. It starts with 40 Health Point instead of 48.[CR]* The first extra live is at 200k points instead of 100k.[CR]* Time runs faster when the 'GO cursor' is flashing.[CR]* Count down of time starts from 30 seconds when a life is lost. This happens every time a character is killed by enemies while remaining time is less than 30 seconds.[CR]* Fruit restores only 12 Health Point (banana 10 Health Point, big red apple 24) instead of 16 in the early 'World revision'.[CR]* A dead Boss restores only 12 Health Point instead of 16 in the early 'World revision'.[CR]* Magic attacks and magic crystals destroy directly enemies flying objects (so you get more experience points). These are wolves archers arrows, skeletons lances and knights archers arrows.[CR]* Mimic Chests release a pool of acid after breaking them.[CR]* New enemies like green lizard spearmen and dark red lizard swordsmen.[CR]* Player doesn't gain the extra strawberry after the killing of the Orc King (the Boss of the first stage).[CR]* The gait of the Wyvern (the Boss of the third and of the fourteenth stage) is different; it has also only triple fireball/iceball attacks.[CR]* Back attacks of the Hydra (the Boss of the fourth stage) are more powerful.[CR]* Additional green apple no more available on the five stage.[CR]* Frontal punch attack of the Cyclops (the Boss of the sixth and fifteenth stage) is faster than in the early 'World revision'.[CR]* New different background music in the last duel with evil red dragon Gildiss.[CR]* A new Gildiss attack : an animated breath of flame after he changes the direction he's facing during the battle.[CR]* Added a new credit sequence with Gildiss and beauty fairy.[CR]

It starts with 40 Health Point instead of 48.[CR]* The first extra live is at 200k points instead of 100k.[CR]* Time runs faster when the 'GO cursor' is flashing.[CR]* Count down of time starts from 30 seconds when a life is lost. This happens every time a character is killed by enemies while remaining time is less than 30 seconds.[CR]* Fruit restores only 12 Health Point (banana 10 Health Point, big red apple 24) instead of 16 in the early 'World revision'.[CR]* A dead Boss restores only 12 Health Point instead of 16 in the early 'World revision'.[CR]* Magic attacks and magic crystals destroy directly enemies flying objects (so you get more experience points). These are wolves archers arrows, skeletons lances and knights archers arrows.[CR]* Mimic Chests release a pool of acid after breaking them.[CR]* New enemies like green lizard spearmen and dark red lizard swordsmen.[CR]* Player doesn't gain the extra strawberry after the killing of the Orc King (the Boss of the first stage).[CR]* The gait of the Wyvern (the Boss of the third and of the fourteenth stage) is different; it has also only triple fireball/iceball attacks.[CR]* Back attacks of the Hydra (the Boss of the fourth stage) are more powerful.[CR]* Additional green apple no more available on the five stage.[CR]* Frontal punch attack of the Cyclops (the Boss of the sixth and fifteenth stage) is faster than in the early 'World revision'.[CR]* New different background music in the last duel with evil red dragon Gildiss.[CR]* A new Gildiss attack : an animated breath of flame after he changes the direction he's facing during the battle.[CR]* Added a new credit sequence with Gildiss and beauty fairy.[CR]

game.name: The King of Dragons (Japan 910805, B-Board 89625B-1)
game.plot: The King of Dragons (c) 1991 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Five Mythical warriors take up arms against the evil dragon, Gildiss and his hordes of protective monsters. Features a level-up system and the ability to switch characters at various points in the game.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Capcom Play System Hardware (CP-S)[CR]B-Board #: 89625B-1[CR]Players: Up to 3 simultaneous[CR]Control per player: 8-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons per player: 2[CR]=> [1] Attack, [2] Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]The King of Dragons was released in July 1991 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 15th video game made for this system.[CR]Known re-release: "The King of Dragons [B-Board 90629B-3]"[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Captain Commando : G.S.M. Capcom 5 - PCCB-00083) on March 21, 1992.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Strange Item :[CR]Ice Star : sometimes in 2P mode at second stage, an ice star appears after breaking the wood cask. It seems it only restores energy like a fruit. [CR]Gold Gauntlet : sometimes at fourth stage, a gold gauntlet appears after breaking the second-last chest. It seems useless. [CR]Cutpurse's Sack : it's a small sack with a light blue question mark that is dropped by Cutpurses after they get hit during the game. A hidden trick or simply a Capcom's joke? [CR]* Gaining extra points :[CR]1) Eat a fruit or a elixir at full energy: this gives 5000 experience points.[CR]2) Hit flying objects like wolves archers arrows, skeletons lances and knights archers arrows.[CR]3) Hit Cutpurse : they take away items like gold's sacks, rubys, pearls, gems, diamonds and fruits.[CR]4) Kill all the green lizard spearmen during the battle with the Wyvern at fourteenth stage (they can release a lot of diamonds or precious).[CR]5) Hit Gildiss fireballs : some of these turns into green apples that at full full energy gives 5000 experience points each-one.[CR]6) Don't use magic attacks or magic crystals at bosses : these kinds of attacks are incredibly more powerful than normal attacks so a boss needs many less hits to kill him.[CR]* BOSSES and POWER-UP WEAPON STRATEGY : middle or end level bosses give experience points for each hit taken while normal monsters give experience points ONLY when they die (it has no matter how strong is the attack, they give ALWAYS the same experience points). [CR]- With Elf, Fighter, Cleric and Dwarf : DON'T power-up your weapon during the game and ALWAYS use the LEVEL-1 WEAPON. So a boss needs many more hits to kill him (remember? more hits > more experience points). To gain extra point it has no matter if character power-up or not bow (for Elf) or shield (for Fighter, Cleric and Dwarf).[CR]- With Wizard : DON'T power-up your weapon during the game and use the LEVEL-1 WEAPON until the wizard can take the LEVEL-5 WEAPON (a wood staff with metal headpiece and red gem/orange flame). This weapon isn't much powerful but a singular attack to a boss increases three times the experience points for each hit. [CR]* INFINITE WOLVES ARCHERS TRICK: At the beginning of the sixth stage on the beach, don't go forward but wait. After a few seconds a blue wolf archer appears and after you kill him, another appears then another one in sequence (then two wolves at a time, then three at a time and then four at a time) to infinity. One single wolf is equal to 1300 experience points, so the player can accumulate points and win a life every 450k points. If the player wants to squeeze millions of points he has to kill wolves very fast and win a life before the timer reaches zero. Then after he rises again with a new life, he starts again to kill wolves and repeats in the same method.[CR]- In the early 'World revision' (July 1991). (Time doesn't run faster when the 'GO cursor' is flashing, so player can kill wolves without going forward (but he isn't forced to do it).[CR]- In the World, Japanese (August 1991) and US revision (September 1991): Time runs faster when the 'GO cursor' is flashing, so the player is forced to go forward step by step, kill a pair of wolves and before the next 'GO cursor' is flashing once, go forward step by step again (this method is very hard).[CR]ADDITIONAL NOTES : Each character has a maximum of 24 level-up during all the game. This means a full bar of energy with 96 Health Point.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Music Composer: Yoko Shimomura[CR]Other staffs: Chin, Tomoshi, Tolaya, Gyo, Shimopi, HK, Yama, Mikiman, Miyao, Iwai, SSS, Mizuho, Hayashi, Manbou, Guych, Dany, Blbon, Ogachy, Hirabe, Wakio[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (March 4, 1994) "The King of Dragons [Model SHVC-EI]" [CR]Nintendo SNES [US] (April 1994) "The King of Dragons [Model SNS-EI-USA]" [CR]Nintendo SNES [EU] (August 1994) "The King of Dragons [Model SNSP-EI-NOE]"[CR]Microsoft XBOX [US] (November 24, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (November 24, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2 [Model SLUS-21473]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [AU] (April 11, 2007) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2 [Model SLES-54561]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (April 13, 2007) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2 [Model SLES-54561]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Sony PSP [JP] (September 7, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model ULJM-05104]" [CR]Sony PSP [US] (October 24, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Reloaded [Model ULUS-10134]" [CR]Sony PSP [EU] (November 10, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Reloaded [Model ULES-00377]" [CR]Sony PSP [AU] (November 16, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Reloaded"[CR]

game.name: Lost Worlds (Japan)
game.plot: Lost Worlds (c) 1988 Capcom. [CR]Two jet-pack wearing marines must battle a powerful enemy force that has seized and inhabited their home planet - now known as 'Dust World' - and restore the planet to its former name of 'Earth'.[CR]Lost Worlds' gameplay features multi-directional shooting, with the Marines being able to rotate through 360 degrees, allowing players to fire in any direction. When killed, enemies drop 'Zenny Coins' which can be used to upgrade weapons and player health at the shops that appear at the halfway point of each level. Forgotten Worlds features superb graphics and ingenious enemy design, and was converted to many different home formats.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware[CR]B-Board #: 88618B-2[CR]B-Board PALs: LWCHR[CR]CPS-B #: CPS-B-01 DL-0411-10001[CR]Players: Up to 2[CR]Control: 8-way joystick, Spinner[CR]Buttons: 1 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Lost Worlds was released in July 1988 in the Japanese arcade. It was the first video game released for this system (Known as 'CP-S No. 01').[CR]The game is known outside Japan as "Forgotten Worlds". Here are some known export releases:[CR]"Forgotten Worlds [B-Board 88618B-2]"[CR]"Forgotten Worlds [B-Board 88621B-2]"[CR]Lost Worlds is the third and final game in Capcom's 'Jet-Pack Hero' trilogy (with the first two games being 1985's "Section Z" and 1986's "Side Arms") and, as with the first two games, is a one or two player sideways scrolling shoot-em-up.[CR]While Lost Worlds isn't a sequel to "Black Dragon", it does share similarities with it: In both games the player fights dragons, and also collects 'ZENNY' coins, money to buy weapons and armour in shops. Also, both games feature intros depicting dragons attacking cities.[CR]The first player character, Unknown Soldier, appears as an assist character in "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes". The second player character appears in "Final Fight" as an enemy member of the Mad Gear gang; he was then called 'Two P' (for 2P, player 2).[CR]The shop music used in this game was later remade and used as the shop music for "SNK vs. Capcom - Card Fighters Clash".[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Daimakaimura : G.S.M. Capcom 1 - D28B-0011) on January 11, 1989.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]The DRESS (lips icon): [CR]Only available on last stage(9)last shop. [CR]Investing 99990 on the DRESS, after clear the final boss the zenny spent on the items you have in your inventory is REFUNDED IN SCORE.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game designers : Akira Yasuda (Akiman), Akira Nishitani (Nin), Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Kihaji Okamoto[CR]Soft programmers : Youchi, Noriko, Takako, Nouchi[CR]Object designers : Kurichan, Takata, Shinsyudon, Sintan, Emetaro[CR]Scroll designers : Miki Chan (Mik), Hanachan, Kuramoyan, Nouochan, Black man[CR]Sound : Tamayo Kawamoto, Yoshihiro Sakaguchi (Yukichan No papa)[CR]Hardware : Shinji Kuchino[CR]Mechatronics : Katuhiko Kamimori[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of Japanese ports. To see ports released in other regions, please see the export version entry; "Forgotten Worlds [B-Board 88618B-2]".[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Mega Drive [JP] (November 18, 1989) "Forgotten Worlds [Model G-4016]" [CR]NEC PC-Engine Super CD-ROM² System (March 27, 1992) [Model NAPR1025] [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (March 2, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model SLPM-66317]"[CR]

game.name: Lost Worlds (Japan Old Ver.)
game.plot: Lost Worlds (c) 1988 Capcom. [CR]Two jet-pack wearing marines must battle a powerful enemy force that has seized and inhabited their home planet - now known as 'Dust World' - and restore the planet to its former name of 'Earth'.[CR]Lost Worlds' gameplay features multi-directional shooting, with the Marines being able to rotate through 360 degrees, allowing players to fire in any direction. When killed, enemies drop 'Zenny Coins' which can be used to upgrade weapons and player health at the shops that appear at the halfway point of each level. Forgotten Worlds features superb graphics and ingenious enemy design, and was converted to many different home formats.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware[CR]B-Board #: 88618B-2[CR]B-Board PALs: LWCHR[CR]CPS-B #: CPS-B-01 DL-0411-10001[CR]Players: Up to 2[CR]Control: 8-way joystick, Spinner[CR]Buttons: 1 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Lost Worlds was released in July 1988 in the Japanese arcade. It was the first video game released for this system (Known as 'CP-S No. 01').[CR]The game is known outside Japan as "Forgotten Worlds". Here are some known export releases:[CR]"Forgotten Worlds [B-Board 88618B-2]"[CR]"Forgotten Worlds [B-Board 88621B-2]"[CR]Lost Worlds is the third and final game in Capcom's 'Jet-Pack Hero' trilogy (with the first two games being 1985's "Section Z" and 1986's "Side Arms") and, as with the first two games, is a one or two player sideways scrolling shoot-em-up.[CR]While Lost Worlds isn't a sequel to "Black Dragon", it does share similarities with it: In both games the player fights dragons, and also collects 'ZENNY' coins, money to buy weapons and armour in shops. Also, both games feature intros depicting dragons attacking cities.[CR]The first player character, Unknown Soldier, appears as an assist character in "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes". The second player character appears in "Final Fight" as an enemy member of the Mad Gear gang; he was then called 'Two P' (for 2P, player 2).[CR]The shop music used in this game was later remade and used as the shop music for "SNK vs. Capcom - Card Fighters Clash".[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Daimakaimura : G.S.M. Capcom 1 - D28B-0011) on January 11, 1989.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]The DRESS (lips icon): [CR]Only available on last stage(9)last shop. [CR]Investing 99990 on the DRESS, after clear the final boss the zenny spent on the items you have in your inventory is REFUNDED IN SCORE.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game designers : Akira Yasuda (Akiman), Akira Nishitani (Nin), Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Kihaji Okamoto[CR]Soft programmers : Youchi, Noriko, Takako, Nouchi[CR]Object designers : Kurichan, Takata, Shinsyudon, Sintan, Emetaro[CR]Scroll designers : Miki Chan (Mik), Hanachan, Kuramoyan, Nouochan, Black man[CR]Sound : Tamayo Kawamoto, Yoshihiro Sakaguchi (Yukichan No papa)[CR]Hardware : Shinji Kuchino[CR]Mechatronics : Katuhiko Kamimori[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of Japanese ports. To see ports released in other regions, please see the export version entry; "Forgotten Worlds [B-Board 88618B-2]".[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Mega Drive [JP] (November 18, 1989) "Forgotten Worlds [Model G-4016]" [CR]NEC PC-Engine Super CD-ROM² System (March 27, 1992) [Model NAPR1025] [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (March 2, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model SLPM-66317]"[CR]

game.name: Muscle Bomber: The Body Explosion (Japan 930713)
game.plot: Muscle Bomber - The Body Explosion (c) 1993 Capcom.[CR]A 1-on-1 fighting game in which players choose from 10 different wrestlers and take to the ring to try and defeat their larger-than-life opponents. Each wrestler has an assortment of moves, including his own special 'super slam'. The object of the game is to win and defend the championship by pinning or putting a submission hold on your opponent.[CR]There are 2 different game modes to select and play : Single Match or Tag Team 'Battle Royal'. In Single Match, players choose to be one of eight wrestlers including 'Mike Hagger', 'Alexander The Grater', 'El Stingray', 'King Rasta Mon', 'Titanic Tim', 'Gunloc', 'Biff Bolshevik' and 'The Great Oni' ('Jumbo Jack' and 'The Scorpion' cannot be selected in this game).[CR]Once a wrestler has been selected, players will compete in a world-wide tournament against the other 9 wrestlers (including 'Jumbo Jack' and 'The Scorpion') in respective matches. In each match, players must defeat each of their respective opponents by a pinfall, count-out or submission in order to proceed to each of the following matches. Once all opponents are defeated, the winner will be crowned champion and players will have to face all opponents again to defend their title.[CR]In Tag Team 'Battle Royal', players can choose to play as any 2 of the 10 wrestlers for their tag team, including 'Jumbo Jack' and 'The Scorpion'. Here, the player and his or her partner have to eliminate both of the 2 wrestlers on the opposing tag team, in order to win the match and proceed to the next. During these matches, if the player is eliminated before his or her partner is, the match will be declared no contest and it will be a draw.[CR]During each bout in this game, metal buckets and/or glass bottles will sometimes be thrown into the ring which can be picked by the players' wrestler(s) and used as weapons against their opponents.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board #: 91634B-2[CR]# of Players: Up to 4[CR]Type of controls (per player): 8-way joystick[CR]# of buttons (per player): 3[CR]=> [1] Attack, [2] Jump, [3] Pin[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Muscle Bomber was released in July 1993 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 27th video game made for CP-S system. It is known outside Japan as "Saturday Night Slam Masters".[CR]Hara Tetsuo, who designed the characters in the Muscle Bomber games, is a popular manga artist in Japan. He is famous for his work on 'Hokuto no Ken' (aka 'Fist of the North Star').[CR]Some characters in the game are based on real life wrestlers. Such examples are the Great Oni, who is based on legendary Japanese wrestler the Great Muta, El Stingray, who is based on Mexican wrestler Lizmark, Alexander the Grater is based on former WCW and IWGP world champion Big Van Vader, and Jumbo Flapjack is based on the late Canadian wrestler Earthquake.[CR]One of the wrestlers is Mike Haggar from the game Final Fight. Also, one of the wrestlers named Gunloc is related to Guile from Street Fighter II. Additionally his clone, named Biff, is a friend of Zangief from Street Fighter II.[CR]King Rasta Mon was the original design for Street Fighter II character Blanka, but rejected later on in favor of the most 'beast-like' design.[CR]Biff Slamkovich appears in the background of Ken's stage in "Street Fighter Alpha 2".[CR]Default highscore table :[CR]CHAMP 100000 CAP[CR]1st 95000 COM[CR]2nd 90000 C P[CR]3rd 85000 SYS[CR]4th 80000 TEM[CR]5th 75000 TOM[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Muscle Bomber - PCCB-00136) on September 17, 1993.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Muscle Bomber - The Body Explosion [CP-S No. 27] (1993)[CR]2. Muscle Bomber Duo - Heat Up Warriors [CP-S No. 28] (1993)[CR]3. Super Muscle Bomber - The International Blowout [Green Board] (1994)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Tomy, Saddy, Koguma[CR]Object Designers : Mount-S, Ikusan Z, Q (Q;clever), Imomushi, Kazz. Ist, Yorio, Tom, Chama(c), Rikagon[CR]Scroll Designers : Buppo, Okachan, Taka[CR]Programmers : H.M.D., B.I.N, Shaver, Semari!, Yu Bono[CR]Sound Designers : Masaki Izutani (T. Yomage), Toshio Kajino (Toshi), Syun Nishigaki (Syun), Kiyo, Nobuhiro Oouchi (Nobu. Oouchi)[CR]Assists : Eripyon. N (Eripon), Ball Boy (Ball-Boy), Yuusuke, Chin, Go, Iwai, Tetsuya., Tenman, Vlad T.[CR]Special Thanks : Yoshiki Okamoto (Kihaji), Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Akira Yasuda (Akiman), Akira Nishitani (Nin), K-Man, Meshi[CR]USA Support : James Goddard (DJames "Mon"), Alex Jimenez, David Winstead (Dr. Dave W.)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]FM Towns Marty [JP] (November 1993) [Model HMF-161] [CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (March 30, 1994) [Model SHVC-ZW][CR]

game.name: Senjou no Ookami II (Japan 900302)
game.plot: 戦場の狼II (c) 1990 Capcom.[CR](Senjou no Ookami II)[CR]The US faces a grave crisis! The former president has been kidnapped by a group of revolutionaries while on a trip on Central Africa meant to promote world peace. Take control of three highly skilled anti-terrorist soldiers and venture through enemy lines to save the former president & annihilate the rebel army in the process. Features solid graphics & sound, plenty of weapons & vehicles to use and hulking bosses to defeat.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware[CR]B-Board ID: 89625B-1[CR]Players: Up to 3[CR]Control per player: 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons per player: 2[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Senjou no Ookami II was released in March 1990 in Japan. It is known outside Japan as "Mercs". [CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Wolf of the Battlefield II'.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (G.S.M. Capcom 3 - PCCB-00030) on May 21, 1990.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* At the end of Stage 1, a large plane rises in front of the player. If you stand .25 to .5 inches up from the bottom of the cliff, and line up so your bullets will hit just to the right of the plane's center, it cannot hit you with its cannon. This takes practice.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Senjou no Ookami (1985)[CR]2. Senjou no Ookami II [CP-S No. 09] (1990)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Chief designer : S. Okano, Tokuro Fujiwara (A. Kume), Kijima[CR]Character designers : Hitoshi Nishio, T. Hayashi[CR]Sound : M. Gotoh[CR]Sound programmer : Yoshihiro Sakaguchi (Y. Sakaguchi)[CR]Programmers : M. Akahori, T. Ohta, Y. Matsui[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Mega Drive [JP] (September 27, 1991) "Senjou no Ookami II [Model G-4051]" [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (November 12, 1998) "Capcom Generation Dai 4 Shou Kokou no Eiyuu [Model T-1235G]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (November 12, 1998) "Capcom Generation Dai 4 Shou Kokou no Eiyuu [Model SLPS-01701]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (March 2, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model SLPM-66317]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Sony PSP [JP] (September 7, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection [Model ULJM-05104]"[CR]

game.name: Magic Sword: Heroic Fantasy (Japan 900623)
game.plot: Magic Sword - Heroic Fantasy (c) 1990 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]The land has been cast in darkness by Drokmar, who has been corrupted by the Black Orb; an artefact that promises immortality to anyone who comes under the influence of the orb's powerful sorcery. Two warriors set out to fight their way through fifty levels of platform beat-em-up, in order to destroy the orb - which lies at the top of the Dragon Tower - and free their lands.[CR]Treasure chests litter the levels which, when smashed open, release treasure items, magic power-ups, keys, food and weapons. As players fight their way through the levels, they will come across a number of trapped prisoners. As long as the heroes are carrying keys, prisoners can be released who will then fight alongside the players, with each prisoner possessing their own unique attacks. Weapons and power-ups can be picked up to aid players in their quest and food can be found and eaten to increase player health.[CR]As the players ascend the tower, they will be granted new magical weapons after each boss they defeat. The player's weapons are affected by a 'magic bar' that charges over time. When fully charged, the weapon has a powerful ranged attack, but when not charged only a close attack is produced. A magical staff will grant increased range attack ability. A magical blast may be generated by pressing the Attack and Jump buttons at once, but costs health.[CR]There are multiple paths in the game, and two separate endings. Hidden doors can be used to skip levels when found - usually by attacking a wall or a particular spot.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board ID: 89625B-1[CR]Players: Up to 2 simultaneously.[CR]Control per player: 8-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons per player: 2[CR]=> [1] Attack, [2] Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Magic Sword was released in June 1990 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 11th video game made for the CP-S system.[CR]Known Export release: "Magic Sword - Heroic Fantasy [B-Board 89624B-3]"[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Street Fighter II : G.S.M. Capcom 4 - PCCB-00056) on March 21, 1991.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Magic Sword items :[CR]1) King crown : magical protection.[CR]2) Gauntlet : increase power.[CR]3) Golden pot : healing magic for partner.[CR]4) Crystal ball : detect treasure boxes.[CR]5) Pedant : double score.[CR]6) Magic potion : increases magic skill.[CR]7) Bell : summons a hostile Lizardman to tame. If you have the Diamond Ring equipped he will kneel to accept you as a partner.[CR]8) Diamond Ring : see Bell.[CR]9) Scroll : brings good luck.[CR]* Partners :[CR]1) Big Man : is strong and has great endurance. His boomerang axe is powerful but slow.[CR]2) Ninja : throws 2 to 5 stars which rebound from walls and ceiling. Fast but not so powerful.[CR]3) Amazon : fires her crossbow continuously. Her attack is swift but lacking in power.[CR]4) Thief : is able to locate hidden treasure chests and traps. His bomb packs quite a wallop, too.[CR]6) Knight : is incredibly adept with his spear and is your strongest ally. He is held in the upper level of the tower.[CR]7) Priest : lacks physical strength and speed but his holy bullets can do grave damage to undead monsters.[CR]8) Wizard : shoots magical missiles. He has the most powerful attack but is slow and not much to speak physically.[CR]9) Lizardman : becomes an ally only when bribed with a diamond ring. He is a brute with great strength, speed and attacking power.[CR]* Secret Doors :[CR]Floor 7 - When you enter the floor, walk left and hit the column. warp to level 11.[CR]Floor 17 - Slash the left side of the last arch. Warps to floor 20.[CR]Floor 21 - Between the imprisoned (knight) and the exit, jump left from the elevated ground while slashing. Warp to floor 24.[CR]Floor 28 - Crouch on the platform above the first pool of acid and slash the space in the middle. Enters RED floors 29 to 32.[CR]Floor 34 - Jump and slash the left side of the the fourth pair of hanging pillars. Warps to floor 36.[CR]Floor 39 - Slash the ledge immediately to the left of the first door after the pit of fire. Warps to floor 42.[CR]Floor 40 - Crouch and slash the space above the ledge before the first pit of spikes. Enters RED floors 41 to 46.[CR]* An extra 1,000,000 points! is available on blue level 30 : there is a wizard there who levitates rocks. Jump and sword him once, and then when he causes the rocks to appear, use magic (both buttons) to turn the rocks into 8K gold pieces. You can do this until time runs out.[CR]* On level 14, go to the second 'door' with a head on top of it, jump and hit the 'nose' several times and two gems will drop down worth 80,000 a piece.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game designers : Yoshimi Ohnishi, Tomoshi Sadamoto, Yoshiki Okamoto[CR]Character designers : Kurisan, E. Nishihara, Keiko Kitayama, T. Saramoto[CR]Art : Y. Fukumoto, M. Kawamura, Y. Maruyama[CR]Title designer : Satoru Yamashita[CR]Sound : M. Gotoh[CR]English story : S. Maxwell[CR]Programmers : Y. Egawa, Y. Tsunazaki, S. Okada, Y. Oronishi[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of Japanese ports. To see ports released outside Japan, please see the Export version entry; "Magic Sword - Heroic Fantasy [B-Board 89624B-3]"[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (May 29, 1992) "Magic Sword [Model SHVC-MD-JPN]"[CR]

game.name: Nemo (Japan 901120)
game.plot: Nemo (c) 1990 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]One night, as Nemo sleeps, he is visited in a dream by the King of Slumberland, who invites Nemo to come and play with the King's daughter, the Princess. Nemo finds himself unable to find the Princess however, so he and 'Flip', a strange companion who also turns up in the dream, decide to explore Slumberland and find the king.[CR]Nemo is a colourful and abstract platform shoot-em-up set in the dream world of Slumberland, a surreal world in which childrens' toys are running amok and must be destroyed. Nemo is armed with a magical staff that emits a burst of magic to destroy the many enemies, some of which require multiple hits. A number of power-ups also appear at regular intervals to aid Nemo in his quest through seven tough stages.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board #: 89625B-1[CR]Players: Up to 2 simultaneously.[CR]Control: 8-Way Joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 2 per player.[CR]=> Magic, Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Nemo was released in November 1990 in Japan. It was known there as the 13th video game made for this system.[CR]Known Export release: "Nemo [B-Board 89624B-3]".[CR]Little Nemo in Slumberland was the original comicstrip from Winsor Mc Kay published in the New York Herald in 1904. He also made the first movie animation around 1910's. Tokyo Movie Shinsha (TMS) in 1990 got the rights to make an animated movie based in the comicstrip, later they gave the rights to Capcom to make the Arcade games.[CR]The second player in Nemo, Flip, appears in the music video of Tom Petty's 'Running down a Dream'.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* New Final Scenes : if you beat the game in one credit, you get special bonus scenes at the end. These parody two other Capcom classics, "Ghouls'n Ghosts" and "Final Fight".[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Popo P, Chin[CR]Chief object designer : Nemotani[CR]Object designers : Hiramacho, Mizuho, Popo P, Chin[CR]Chief scroll designer : Tanupooh[CR]Scroll designers : Oyuu, Konomi (Powerful Konomi), Taiyaki[CR]Chief programmer : CBX[CR]Programmers : Cherry, Wakio[CR]Sound composer : Shimopii[CR]Character supporters : Popo P, Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), CBX[CR]Character coordinator : Nemotani[CR]Character effecter : Chin[CR]Editors : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Popo P, Chin, CBX[CR]Director : Yoshiki Okamoto[CR]

game.name: Pang! 3: Kaitou Tachi no Karei na Gogo (Japan 950511)
game.description: Pang! 3: Kaitou Tachi no Karei na Gogo (Japan 950511)
game.title_clean: Pang! 3: Kaitou Tachi no Karei na Gogo
game.plot: Pang! 3 - Kaitou Tachi no Karei na Gogo (c) 1995 Mitchell.[CR]The second sequel to the superb 1989 original, Pang! 3 retains the same gameplay of its predecessors but adds vastly improved graphics and a choice of three difficulty levels; Beginner, Normal and Panic. On both the 'Normal' and 'Panic' skill levels, players can choose from 4 different playable characters; each possessing different strengths and weaknesses, such as a double harpoon or quick shots. On the beginner level, players can only use the Mexican character.[CR]Another notable difference is in the game's use of backdrops : instead of the world landmarks of the first two games, Pang! 3 features classical works of art in the form of paintings and sculptures.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System" hardware.[CR]B-Board #: 94916-10[CR]Players: Up to 2[CR]Control per player: 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons per player: 3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Pang! 3 was released in May 1995 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 31th video game made for this system.[CR]The subtitle of this game translates from Japanese as 'The Magnificent Afternoon of the Mysterious Thieves'.[CR]Known export releases : [CR][EU] "Pang! 3 [B-Board 94916-10]" [CR][US] "Buster Buddies [B-Board 94916-10]"[CR]Here is a detailed list of famous paintings appearing in this order :[CR]'La Bohémienne Endormie' by Henri Julien Rousseau, 1897.[CR]'The Scream' by Edvard Munch, 1893.[CR]'Thirty-Six Views of Mt. Fuji' by Katsushika Hokusai, 19th century.[CR]'Still Life : Vase with twelve sunflowers' by Vincent Van Gogh, 1888.[CR]'Les Glaneuses' by Jean Francois Millet, 1857.[CR]'Moulin Rouge - La Goulue' by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, 1891.[CR]'Le Dejeuner des Canotiers' by Pierre August Renoir, 1881.[CR]'Portrait of Leopold Zborowski' by Amedeo Modigliani, 1916.[CR]'La Nascita di Venere' by Sandro Filipepi aka 'Botticelli', 1485.[CR]'La Grande Odalisque' by Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres, 1814.[CR]'Mona Lisa' by Leonardo da Vinci, 1506.[CR]'Actor Otani Oniji II as Yakko Edohei' by Toshusai Sharaku, 1794.[CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the high score table. If you try, it gets changed to '???'.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Stage Select : select Normal mode while putting the joystick down.[CR]* Expert Mode : select Normal mode with 1P and 2P SHOT buttons simultaneously.[CR]* Win 500 points In Panic Mode : hold down the joystick and 500 points will be added to your score every few seconds.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Pang (1989)[CR]2. Super Pang (1990)[CR]3. Pang! 3 - Kaitou Tachi no Karei na Gogo [CP-S No. 31] (1995)[CR]4. Mighty! Pang (2000)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Da., Futoshi Kuwahara, S. Obata (Manhattan)[CR]Programmers : Cat, Yoshinobu Inada (Ine), T. Misawa[CR]Character designers : Imo, Tom-Pang, S. Kitamura, Ban, Miyo.[CR]Artists : Y.N, Akagi, Joe, A. Hamada[CR]Music composer : Isao Abe (Oyaji)[CR]Sound designers : Toshio Kajino, Hiroaki Kondo[CR]Supervisor : Yoshiki Okamoto (Kihaji Okamoto)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (March 14, 1997) "Super Pang Collection [Model SLPS-00360]"[CR]
